narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This is an excellent class taught by a great instructor who is unfortunately leaving after this semester. It would be in the best interest of the School to make finding a comparable replacement a top priority
Note that i took this class for 2 credits and did not take part in the client practicum.

The TA was crucial to my success in the class and my understanding of material glossed over in class. She was patient, reliable, responsive, and genuinely seemed to both enjoy the material and helping students. Overall, she was excellent!

Q 7a. One of the best instructors I've ever had - great at explaining technical concepts in a way that is simple to understand. Matt Eckelmann will be sorely missed by FES students. I would have taken any class taught by him.Q7b. Fantastic TA - very dedicated and willing to meet up with students to help.Q10. I think this is an essential class for anyone seriously considering working in industry and manufacturing. More classes at FES should be skills-based as this one was.
Class is a whole lot of work.

Question 3: I wish I had more time to do the readings, but because between those and the assignments I didn't, I lost out on that additional understanding of the material. Cutting down on the reading might help make it feel more manageable.
The best course at FES.
Very valuable course for understanding the principles of LCA and the specifics of Sima Pro software.
I think he homework assignments could be better, sometimes the questions were to open ended and I didnt know what I was doing. (you can do it but you dont understand exactly what it means)

Professor Eckelman has prepared an excellent curriculum for learning the theory and practice of life cycle impact assessments. I am very glad I was able to learn from him during his final semester at Yale.
The quality instruction on the theory and practical application of LCA, along with the opportunity to apply that learning to a full LCA project.
Doing LCAs through the homework problem sets.

The professor was one of the best I've ever had. The assignments were very helpful to understanding the material. The best part is that I learned an entirely new skill that is directly applicable to my future career ambitions.
The projects!
Patience and teaching style of instructor.

Excellent course! The best course of my semester. Learned so much in the computer program, SimaPro. Loved working with an outside organization. Was excellent professional experience. Matt Eckelman is an excellent professor.

The practical skills it taught, and the overall framework through which to think about the lifecycle of a product or service. Also, the chance to work with a real life client to apply those skills is critical.
Learning LCA!
The final project and Matt Eckelman is an amazing teacher.
The topic is essential for environmental managers; Matt is a terrific teacher. It's quite disappointing that he will no longer be at Yale.
Matt is a fantastic professor and this course is incredibly valuable for learning LCA. Another great part of the class is the practicum aspect and working for a client and doing a real LCA study.
the course content

The practical learning. There are so many courses at professional schools that focus on theory without really giving students any hands-on experience. This class was by far one of the best I have taken.
Learning the software and getting a deeper understanding of LCA.

To get to use SimaPro in an aignment for a real world client.
Learn how to use SimaPro and get an idea of LCA jargon.
Excellent mix of theoretical and applied lessons. The opportunity to put our knowledge and skills to work in a client-based situation was extremely valuable.
Matt's a great professor, he will be missed.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: We were not able to use one of the well known-LCA modeling softwares, GABBI - which would have been beneficial to work with as well.
Getting the software environment working properly from day 1.
No complaints.

Assignments seemed poorly formed/written, and were often very difficult to understand. The TF even had a hard time understanding what the professor wanted, and points were often taken off because the question was very uncertain.

I don't have a way to address this comment, but I will make it in hopes that someone with more experience could some up with a solution: It seems to me that the likelihood of learning SimaPro and LCA concepts are easy enough to learn before a semester is up, and the teaching course is well designed to accomplish this with good time remaining. However, to be a good LCA practitioner, it's all about making good/best decisions, and that comes with extensive experience that can't be captured in class length (though it can begin to be captured through the final project and interactions with instructor about the project, expertise that is shared, etc). However, if there is a way in final classes to talk about what constitutes good decision-making through specific case studies or something other than just the readings on topics might be interesting. It as it this point in last few weeks of class that I guess I'm wondering if there is a way for teacher to be more assertive/vocal/lecture-oriented about how to cultivate good decision-making, or looking at specific instances if possible, would be good.This is not a call for a radical shift in last few weeks, but a slightly different addition to the usual mix which is good.

Many concepts were learned quite quickly, and we used them in our project with the outside organization, so had to access the professor and TA for help. They were always available. There is so much to learn and it's hard to cram into 1 semester, so we weren't able to cover many of the concepts very in depth.

I thought the few classes at the end where we talked about "special topics" could have been a bit better. The discussions lasted way too long and so few people in the class did the reading that it was painful at times when the professor was attempting to solicit responses from people. I think maybe only doing one of those "special topics" classes would be necessary, and spending the other class either reviewing stuff we already learned earlier in the class or doing multiple classes on certain topics (i.e. a crash course in how to do very basic things in SimaPro) would be useful.
Full access to the pro version of the software, and very clear explanations of the conceptual material. There was a lot I didn't understand after the lectures.
FES should have kept Matt
It should have had many fewer students. In the course listing, enrollment is limited to 18, but that wasn't the case this semester. A smaller class would have been great.
I think the course could be improved by having more in-class demonstrations of using SimaPro. While these are tedious I think it would be very helpful if Matt showed us more aspects of SimaPro.
I think it was perfect.
The homeworks could be phrased more carefully.
This class was very good.
the problem sets
Reliable access to server-based life cycle assessment software tools.
I felt the homework could have been more focused on getting students to truly master SimaPro's functionality.

I thought that both Matt and the TA were extremely helpful on a one-on-one basis, and did their best to make themselves available outside of class whenever we needed it. In fact, I thought Matt was even more effective on a one-on-one basis than in class, which is understandable. Jooyoung was really helpful on homework assignments as well and went out of her way to be available for us.
Both were very available, and great at answering questions.
Great-- always there to help out, especially since the work was very challenging.
Matt and Jooyoung definitely went above and beyond typical instructors/TAs in offering their time and assistance whenever questions arose. They get an A+ on this front.
JooYoung was very available to help us.
Good

Matt and Jooyoung were always so willing to help students outside of office hours and by email. Thank you so much to Jooyoung for sitting with me at Kroon for hours on weekends helping me understand and complete assignments.
Very good availability of both instructor and TA, with helpful guidance for problem sets and good advice in general.
I contacted both, and they were both really helpfull
My problem sets couldn't be completed without TA's help. SimaPro can be frustrating but she helped me understood it very well.
Jooyoung was a fantastic TA who was available essentially whenever we needed her. She was always extremely well prepared to discuss and assisnt with the problem sets.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This class provided one of the only opportunities to learn a clearly marketable skill. I expect to use LCA as a professional, and am glad I was able to take it.

I think this course should be a central class to the industrial ecology track. I think more classes should mimic this style and focus practical skill building. Many of the industrial ecology classes are "soft science" and stay in theory. I felt that this class actually will give me a heads up from my competitors when applying for professional positions and when trying to develop practical and implementable solutions once I get a position.

I don't have much background in this area, but it's something I found really interesting and wanted to learn more about, I could definitely see myself doing future research projects and working with stakeholders, etc on similar work that I have done this semester.

While I don't know how much LCA i will be doing in my professional career, I think it is an extremely valuable and sought-after skill that I will have that lots of my professional "competition" won't, and even just understanding the full lifecycle of a product/service is incredibly valuable to what I want to do professionally.
It seems like at least an overview of LCA should be required for all FES students. It is a fascinating insight into how the true impact of anything is calculated.
It was perfect; best course I have taken.
This course fits will into my overall program. Though it is not a course I initially planned to take, having taken it, I can't imagine graduating from FES without it.

As I'm interested in corporate sustainability and green business, this class gave me a great skill that can be used in this field. LCA is growing in use and popularity so it's a great skill to have on your resume.

As an architect, the performance of each material, as well as the building or a community as a whole, relies on the understanding of it aas a whole system. Only life cycle analysis can offer a fair, comprehensive way to compare a diversity of options to each other in terms of impacts on human health and the environment.
Fits into an 'energy' program well because of analysis of embodied energy and total product greenhouse gas emissions.
I dont know if I will become a Life cycle Practitioner but its nice to understand how this studies are made, and its limitations.
yes

This course was essential to building my quantitative and applied skills. Having taken the course I would feel comfortable accepting an internship doing LCA assessments and/or carbon footprinting this summer.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To be able to conduct LCA's as a professional consultant.
To understand how complex the process of determining environmental impacts is, what data is available, and what assumptions must be made.

Because LCA is a technical methodology that can be used to evaluate and find solutions for manufacturing. It is an essential skill for anyone interested in reforming material use and waste of anything manufactured.
To gain the knowledge and the skills of life cycle assessment to continue with this on my future career life.
After working this summer and getting exposed to LCA, fit perfectly into my program of study. Wanted more exposure to understand ways to use LCA.

I took this course because I wanted the skills to be able to use LCA if/when necessary in my professional career. I also wanted to see if LCA itself might be of enough interest to me to do solely as my professional career. I realized that I don't want to only do LCA, but that I do hope it is part of whatever I do do.
I am interested in doing this kind of work and wanted the basics/to dip my toe in.
LCA is my main interest.
I took this course to learn LCA so that I would have a basic understanding of the software and how it can be used in the business world.
To learn the basics of LCA
I took it to understand why some building materials are better (greener, more sustainable) than others.

To get a broader understanding of what a product or a service carries in its wake in terms of energy consumption, material consumption, ... and to understand the limitations and merits of published LCA analyses, and all the 'grains of salt' with which they should be interpreted.
I wanted to know LCA to see if I wanted to become an LCA practitioner.
to learn how to use Simapro
To learn about the current state of the field of life cycle impact assessments and how to actually conduct impact assessments.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: We worked on a client-based LCA project as a group, which allowed us a chance to put our learning into action and work through an LCA with others in the class. Much greater advantage to this approach than doing one alone.
n/a
Great for 2 minds to work on a complex project. Because of the complexity, the time commitment was higher than original expectations.

The work group was essential in completing our client project - I could never have done it on my own. I also think that because it forced us to combine our skills and knowledge in such a new subject matter in order to complete the assignment, we all benefited from what each other brought to the table.
advantages - different perspectives. disadvantages - some people are more perfectionist, leading to wasted time.
Loved my group work- very effective and very fun

Advantages: distributing work forthe final project.Disadvantages: the group work creates an incentive for the group to operate at the "lowest common denominator", i.e. the group works at the level of the person with the least knowledge and the least motivation. This has little to do with this course specifically but is simply how these things work.

The group work for the practicum aspect of this course was really wonderful. I had a great time working with my partner and got so much out of the group work. We worked really well together and learned from each others' strengths. Highly recommend it!

It has been a pleasure to work with my group partner, Sebastian Ramirez, to create a report that evaluates six roof waterproofing assemblies for our client, Yale Facilities. As a team, we were better able to distribute the work load and teach each other practical and conceptia skills needed for the assignment.
The advantage was that the work was divided up so there isn't too much pressure on one person to complete assignments, the disadvantage is having a slacker as a partner.
I was able to bring my number skills to the team, and my teamates were very helpful with their writing and design skills. Its nice to work with people that complements you.
comparing answers

Working in groups for the problem sets was not required, but inevitably improved the quality of my work. The final consulting projects were executed in small teams and made it possible to produce substantial work products for our clients in a relatively short period of time.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do the readings and participate in class discussions, and dig into the early assignments as they will help train you for your final project.

I chose to take this class for 2 credits, which means I had to attend lectures, do the readings and do the problem sets, but not have to do the large final client project. If you just want to learn about LCA to understand what it is good for, as opposed to learning LCA to one day going to go do LCAs in your professional work life, than skipping out on the client practicum is a good arrangement.
To start the group project early and feel free making assumptions when the client does not deliver - as this is a common issue for consultants.
Sorry kids, course no longer being offered. Find it somewhere, because LCA rocks.
Start collecting data early and running models as early as possible. Seek help from professor and TA. They were excellent!

Definitely be prepared to put a lot of time into this course, especially if you hope to get a lot out of it. I would also highly recommend participating in a client project, as it gives you experience using the skills you learn in class in a real world scenario. Don't be afraid toask questions, and expect to seek out the professor and TAs outside of class to really gain a full understanding of the course. I wasn't able to keep up with the readings, but doing so would be really helpful.
be aggressive in getting the knowledge you feel you need/want
Take this course! (though it no longer exists with Matt)
Do the readings early in the course and be conscientious about understanding the software and key concepts early on.

Absolutely take this course if you'd like to learn more about LCA and the life cycle impacts of products. Matt is a fantastic professor and dedicated to the course. He was very available for help on the practicum project and gave great guidance. The class will give you a great introduction for how to use SimaPro, the limits of LCA analysis, and how businesses are using LCA today. Highly recommend taking this course. Get an early start on the practicum project and hound your clients for data!
Take this course for 3 credits if you do not have any prior LCA experience
Take it. Very useful.
Do the readings as they provide important support for the lectures.
Start your project early
very practical and useful. take it!
Set aside plenty of time for the problem sets. Take advantage of the full 3-credit consulting based credit option.
